CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 8, 1955, pg. 6 reads: "Golden Age Hobbyists - The third annual Golden Age Hobby Show and Sale, sponsored by the Health and Welfare Federation of Allegheny County and the Pittsburgh Press, was held form Sept. 29 to Oct. 3 at the Arts and Crafts Center, 6300 Fifth Avenue. Among the hobbyists who personified the saying that "a hobby is a symbol  of something made for pure joy" ...Frank S. Spangler,77, of 1140 Wheeler Street,...shows a redecorated wastepaper basket...Other entrants, not shown, were Mrs. Cornelia Young, of the Lemington Avenue Home, who although partially blind, crocheted a rug, and John Writt, 80, who fabricated a "mobile," a hanging collection of suspended card board figures, and painted several pictures as his entries.  The Social Service Department of the Mount Lebanon Women's Club, Mrs. Donald O. Northrup, chairman, on Thursday, gave a reception at the Arts and Crafts Center for the exhibitors. Some visitors to the hobby show were greatly impressed by he various entries and especially those of "Miss Dolly" after they learned of the hobbyist's age and viewed the exacting work that required patience and nimble fingers.  "I worked on my entries, the child's dress and the cocktail apron of black net, and did not show them to anybody until they were finished," Miss Dolly, twice a blue-ribbon winner, said.  Mrs. Williams, who said she first started making quilts as a "really young girl" in Rome, Ga., also entered an Eastern Star Handkerchief...-Harris PHotos."
TitMainTitle: Folding table with display of Frank S. Spangler's vases, pitchers, and waste baskets decorated with figures and abstract patterns, for the Pittsburgh Press Golden Age Hobby Show
